instruction: How were the Raman spectral features and machine-learning model used to predict the growth/no growth response of previously unseen bacteria in the related study?
Output:
In the related study, the researchers used Raman spectral features and a machine-learning model to predict the growth/no growth response of previously unseen bacteria. They isolated twenty-one strains of bacteria from seven commercially available fresh-cut vegetables and acquired twenty Raman spectra of single cells for each isolated strain. 

To evaluate the growth/no growth responses of each strain, the researchers exposed them to two levels of sodium acetate concentrations, two incubation temperatures, and eight sampling times. They used optical density to confirm the growth limit conditions. 

The Raman spectra of the twenty strains and their forty-eight growth/no growth responses were then used to train an artificial neural network model. This model was designed to predict the growth/no growth of unknown bacteria. 

The researchers tested the model by using it to predict the growth/no growth of twenty-one unknown bacteria. The model achieved an overall accuracy of 90% in predicting the growth/no growth of these unknown bacteria. 

The use of Raman spectroscopy and machine learning in this study allowed for the rapid characterization of unknown bacterial growth. This has significant implications for the food manufacturing industry, where unknown bacteria are frequently encountered.
